The Biden Administration's national COVID-19 strategy 57 main goals Restore trust with the American people Mount a safe, effective, comprehensive vaccination campaign Mitigate spread through expanding masking, testing, treatment, data, workforce, and clear public health standards Immediately expand emergency relief and exercise the Defense Production Act Safely reopen schools, businesses, and travel, while protecting workers Protect those most at risk and advance equity, including across racial, ethnic and rural/urban lines Restore U.S. leadership globally and build better preparedness for future threats Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. Vaccines: Current status and new developments 7In Development Approved Moderna and Pfizer mRNA vaccines Effective against current variants1,2 59.1 million doses administered in the United States3Johnson & Johnson4 Viral vector vaccine Effective in preventing severe disease Single shot required Basic refrigeration requirements EUA anticipated AstraZeneca Unlikely to be available until late spring5 Merck Development discontinued for Health Plan, Inc. Before getting the vaccine: Prioritization and eligibility 9 Prioritization phases are established by the CDC. oState governments can refine prioritization based on supply and state demographics oAs vaccine providers receive more supply, they'll continue to move through higher priority groups more quickly Eligible individuals can get the vaccine, at no cost, from any provider that has been approved as a COVID-19 vaccine distributor by their state's department of health To find out when you or your employees might be able to get the vaccine, see your state's guidelines Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. All rights reserved. May not be reproduced in any form without the written permission of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. 1FDA.gov, 2Pfizer.com, 3NPR.org 10What it takes to get Emergency Use Authorization In order to apply for EUA, companies must1: Enroll 30K+ participants in phase 3 clinical trial oPfizer enrolled more than 43K2 oModerna enrolled 30K3 Share adequate preliminary safety data Before granting EUA, the FDA will:1 Review safety data from phase 1 and 2 clinical trials Review preliminary safety data from phase 3 Evaluate the chemistry, manufacturing, and controls information to ensure quality and consistency During phase 3 clinical trials, companies release primary efficacy analysis, demonstrating that the vaccine works Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. May not be reproduced in any form without the written permission of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. 11 Building confidence: How you can lead Lead by example Show how leaders are participating Share success stories got a flu shot during the 2018-2019 flu season (between July 2018 and May 2019).Adult vaccination rates were consistently low even before the coronavirus.Vaccine hesitancy isn't newof U.S. adultsEncourage active roles in vaccination and continuing prevention Authorize mentors and leaders Strike a caring and empathetic tone Provide channels for safe discussionConsider social and cultural factors Understand that cultural experiences are diverse and unique Make it easy to get the vaccine by providing time off or transportation access 47 % Source: APA.org Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. Getting vaccinated: Second doses, side effects, and records 12 For Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, the second dose is the same as the first It's best to get second vaccines from the same location as the first Data will eventually show up in Kaiser Permanente medical records oYou must keep a record of your vaccine as well Timing is important, but not critical Side effects are typically mild to moderate, and more common with second doses Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. It's possible to show symptoms after the first vaccination Most people should still get the second vaccination as scheduled Check with your doctor if you have questions"What happens if I contract the virus between the first and second dose?"Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. All rights reserved. May not be reproduced in any form without the written permission of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. After vaccination: Prevention and protection Vaccine effectiveness builds over time Asymptomatic spreading may be possible after vaccination To be safe, you should act as if you can still pass the virus oContinue to wear a mask over your nose and mouth oWash your hands thoroughly and often oStay at least 6 feet away from others 14 Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. "Double-masking" may provide extra protection Layering a fabric mask over a high-quality surgical mask is recommended Copyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. All rights reserved. May not be reproduced in any form without the written permission of Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. Long-term vaccination considerations: Don't delay care 16 Work with your doctor to manage chronic conditions Connect with your doctor to schedule delayed preventive screenings or care You have options for getting care safely For emergency issues: Call 911 or go to the nearest hospitalFor non-emergency issues: Email your care team, schedule a telehealth appointment or call the 24/7 advice lineCopyright © 2021 Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. Encourage — and model — these healthy behaviors to help keep your employees safe.
